prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the [CII] broad wings of SDSSJ2310+18
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observation is aimed at detecting and mapping the broad wings of the [CII] line tracing the outflow in this quasar

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since the outflow is expected to have velocities up to about +- 1000 km/s we have configured SPW1 and SPW2 to be contiguous and slightly overlapping, and the [CII] redshifted frequency is located at the intersection of the two SPW's. The other two SPW's will sample the continuum. We have selected the coarser resolution of the FDM mode. Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the data to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s. For the same reason we do not use TDM mode.

We are mostly focused in detecting the very extended outflows that our past IRAM PdBI observation has shown to extend to 10" in one target, and that cosmological simulations expect to extend even further, on scales of 20" or even 30". C32-2 and ACA enable us to achieve the required sensitivity on such large scale, while C32-2 also enable us to achieve a resolution of 0.8" which is needed to identify compact outflowing clumps.

We do not yet know the intensity of the broad [CII] line in these quasars. Since their [CII] narrow emission is similar to what observed in J1148, we assume for simplicity that also the broad component has a similar intensity (scaled to the specific frequency). Therefore, we take the sensitivity achieved with IRAM PdBI to detect the [CII] outflow in J1148 (Maiolino et la. 2012, Cicone et al. 2015) and we require for all five quasars to reach a homogenous sensitivity that is two times deeper than what achieved for IRAM in J1148, i.e. a sensitivity of 0.07 mJy/beam in a bandwidth corresponding to the velocity extension of the wings, i.e. typically 900 km/s. We have performed a simulation of the ALMA observation, including both the 12m array in compact C32-2 (40 min on-source) configuration (yielding a bream of 0.8", but sensitive to scale up to 11") and the ACA (1 hour on-source). As input for the ALMA simulation we have used the cosmological simulation of quasar feedback obtained by Costa et al. (2015). The resulting simulation is shown in Fig.3c, illustrating that such configuration with these time integration achieve the required sensitivity and can recover the outflow extensing on scales of 20". Note that the integration time estimated by the AOT is dominated by the TP antennae. Finally note taht the line peak given in the AOT does not refer to the peak of the [CII] narrow component, but the expected maximum peak intensity of the wings, based on J1148. The S/N inferred by the AOT is apparently high because it refers to the expected peak flux of the distribution, but we aim at detecting with good S/N also more extended and diffuse outflowing gas, as shown in the simulation of Fig.3b.

Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the dta to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Mapping the [CII] broad wings of ULAS J 1319+09
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observation is aimed at detecting and mapping the broad wings of the [CII] line tracing the outflow in this quasar

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since the outflow is expected to have velocities up to about +- 1000 km/s we have configured SPW1 and SPW2 to be contiguous and slightly overlapping, and the [CII] redshifted frequency is located at the intersection of the two SPW's. The other two SPW's will sample the continuum. We have selected the coarser resolution of the FDM mode. Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the data to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s. For the same reason we do not use TDM mode.

We are mostly focused in detecting the very extended outflows that our past IRAM PdBI observation has shown to extend to 10" in one target, and that cosmological simulations expect to extend even further, on scales of 20" or even 30". C32-2 and ACA enable us to achieve the required sensitivity on such large scale, while C32-2 also enable us to achieve a resolution of 0.8" which is needed to identify compact outflowing clumps.

Since the emission of the [CII] in the outflow (broad wings) is not necessarily related to the core of the [CII] component already detected in cycle 0 (but it depend on the quasar luminosity, reponsible for the outflow, and on the evolutionary stage of the quasar), we use the sensitivity achieved with IRAM PdBI to detect the [CII] outflow in a similar quasar (J1148, Maiolino et la. 2012, Cicone et al. 2015, which has similar luminosity ad similar redshift as the quasars proposed in this sample) and we require for all five quasar to reach a homogenous sensitivity that is two time deeper than what achieved by IRAM in J1148, i.e. a sensitivity of 0.07 mJy/beam in a bandwidth corresponding to the velocity extension of the wings, i.e. typically 900 km/s. We have performed a simulation of the ALMA observation, including both the 12m array in compact C32-2 (40 min on-source) configuration (yielding a bream of 0.8", but sensitive to scale up to 11") and the ACA (1 hour on-source). As input for the ALMA simulation we have used the cosmological simulation of quasar feedback obtained by Costa et al. (2015). The resulting simulation is shown in Fig.3b, illustrating that such configuration with these time integration achieve the required sensitivity and can recover the outflow extensing on scales of 20". Note that the integration time estimated by the AOT is dominated by the TP antennae. Finally note that the line peak flux given in the AOT does not refer to the peak of the [CII] narrow component, but the expected maximum peak intensity of the wings, based on J1148. The S/N inferred by the AOT is apparently high because it refers to expected peak flux of the distribution, but we aim at detecting with good S/N also more extended and diffuse outflowing gas, as shown in the simulation of Fig.3b.

Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the dta to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s.

We do not yet know the intensity of the broad [CII] line in these quasars. Since their [CII] narrow emission is similar to what observed in J1148, we assume for simplicity that also the broad component has a similar intensity. We have performed a simulation of the ALMA observation, including both the 12m array in compact C32-2 (40 min on-source) configuration (yielding a bream of 0.8", but sensitive to scale up to 11") and the ACA (1 hour on-source). Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the dta to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Copy of Mapping the [CII] broad wings of SDSSJ1044-01
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observation is aimed at detecting and mapping the broad wings of the [CII] line tracing the outflow in this quasar

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since the outflow is expected to have velocities up to about +- 1000 km/s we have configured SPW1 and SPW2 to be contiguous and slightly overlapping, and the [CII] redshifted frequency is located at the intersection of the two SPW's. The other two SPW's will sample the continuum. We have selected the coarser resolution of the FDM mode. Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s. For the same reason we do not use TDM mode.

We are mostly focused in detecting the very extended outflows that our past IRAM PdBI observation has shown to extend to 10" in one target, and that cosmological simulations expect to extend even further, on scales of 20" or even 30". C32-2 and ACA enable us to achieve the required sensitivity on such large scale, while C32-2 also enable us to achieve a resolution of 0.8" which is needed to identify compact outflowing clumps.

We do not yet know the intensity of the broad [CII] line in these quasars. Finally note taht the line peak given in the AOT does not refer to the peak of the [CII] narrow component, but the expected maximum peak intensity of the wings, based on J1148. The S/N inferred by the AOT is apparently high because it refers to the expected peak flux of the distribution, but we aim at detecting with good S/N also more extended and diffuse outflowing gas, as shown in the simulation of Fig.3b.

Data averaging by a factor of 10 is acceptable. However, we prefer not to average further the dta to avoid losing potentially important information. Indeed, the numerical simulations show that the individual clumps can have velocity structures of the order of a few 10 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: So far there is only one single detection of a quasar driven massive outflows in the early Universe, close to the reionization epoch, at z~6. However, comparison with models have shown that in such a quasar the outflow is not powerful enough to clean the galaxy of its gas content and to prevent gas accretion from the cosmic filaments. Hence, the feedback process observed in this object seems not capable of quenching star formation as it was suggested by other scenarios. However, this quasar is not fully exploiting its potential and it could potentially drive an outflow an order of magnitude more powerful. We propose deep [CII] observations of a sample of five quasars at z~6, in compact configuration and by also exploiting ACA, to detect very extended massive outflows. The data will reveal whether other quasars in the early Universe are driving much more extreme outflows, with a kinetic power close to the maximum achievable by these systems, that could account for the quenching of star formation in massive galaxies at high-z.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
